Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is preparing to try a new skateboard trick on a steep, uneven ramp.
Situation2: Most callers are receptive, and occasional simple questions arise that the script already covers.
Story: I was on my lunch break, headset still around my neck, when I saw my stepbrother, Jamie, dragging his battered skateboard toward the old ramp behind our house. He flashed me a grin, announcing he was about to try a trick he’d only watched online. My stomach twisted. As his step-sibling, I was supposed to look out for him, make sure he didn’t do anything reckless. But my phone buzzed—a customer was calling back, and I was expected to answer, to handle any objections smoothly, just like the script said. I could already hear my supervisor’s voice in my head, reminding me that every call mattered, that I couldn’t let personal distractions interfere. Jamie was already climbing the ramp, helmet askew, and I could see the uneven cracks in the concrete. My heart pounded as I weighed the headset in my hand, torn between the duty to my job and the responsibility I felt for Jamie’s safety. I stood frozen, caught between two worlds, each demanding my full attention.
